sentences.text: This is the Earth
The Earth has land, and the Earth has sea
There is more sea than land
Seventy percent of the Earth is sea, and thirty percent of the Earth is land
Oceans are large areas of sea
The Earth has three oceans
The Pacific Ocean, the Atlantic Ocean, and the Indian Ocean
Continents are large areas of land
The Earth has six continents
The Eurasian Continent, the African Continent, the North American Continent, the South American Continent, the Australian Continent, and the Antarctic Continent
Islands are small areas of land
Islands are not part of a continent
Japan is an island country
Japan is not part of a continent
Iceland is also an island country
Iceland is not part of a continent
Regions are groups of continents and islands
Europe and Asia are regions
Europe plus Asia equals Eurasia
The Earth has six Regions: North America, South America, Africa, Europe, Asia, and Oceania
Japan is not part of a continent, but Japan is part of the region of Asia
Iceland is not part of a continent, but Iceland is part of the region of Europe
Oceania has many small island countries
Island countries have a lot of sea
Landlocked countries have no sea
Switzerland has no sea; it is a landlocked country
Many countries in Africa are landlocked countries
The highest place on the Earth is the top of Mount Everest
Mount Everest is eight thousand eight hundred forty-eight meters high
The lowest place on the Earth is the bottom of Mariana Trench
Mariana Trench is ten thousand nine hundred twenty meters deep
The Earth looks round and smooth because it is very big
Mount Everest is much smaller than the Earth
Antarctica is bigger than Australia
There are tall mountains in Antarctica
Thick ice covers Antarctica
The ice is two thousand four hundred meters thick on average
The ice is very thick under the South Pole
There are more than one hundred ninety countries in the world.
Some countries have very large land areas.
Russia is more than forty-five times as large as Japan.
Canada is more than twenty-six times as large as Japan.
China is more than twenty-five times as large as Japan.
Some countries have very large populations.
Japan has a large population.
About one hundred twenty-six million people.
This is number eleven in the world.
But two countries have more than eleven times as many people as Japan.
About one billion four hundred forty million in China and about one billion three hundred eighty million in India.
China is number one in the world and India is number two.
The United States also has a large population.
About three hundred thirty-one million people.
This is number three in the world.
There are fourteen countries with populations of over one hundred million people.
Some countries have very small land areas.
The country with the smallest land area is Vatican City.
Vatican City is about the same size as Hirosaki Park.
Monaco is about four times the size of Hirosaki Park.
Nauru is about the same size as Inakadate Village.
Tuvalu is a little bit bigger than Inakadate Village.
Vatican City has less than one thousand people.
Nauru has about ten thousand people.
Tuvalu has about twelve thousand people.
But Monaco has about thirty-four thousand people.
These countries have high population densities.
Population density is population divided by land area.
Many large countries have low population densities.
These three countries don’t have much rain.
Japan’s population density is three hundred thirty-three per square kilometer.
This is number twenty-five in the world.
Countries have names.
India’s name comes from the Indus River.
The Philippines’ name comes from King Philipp of Spain.
Colombia’s name comes from Christopher Columbus.
Ecuador’s name comes from Spanish for Equator.
Countries have flags.
The United Kingdom is a union of four countries.
The flag of the United Kingdom is three flags in one.
The nickname of this flag is the Union Jack.
We can see the Union Jack on many flags in Oceania.
These countries were all colonies of the United Kingdom.
We can see the Southern Cross on many flags in the Southern Hemisphere.
There is a star and crescent on the flags of many Muslim countries.
This was the symbol of the Turkish Ottoman Empire.
Countries have national borders.
Many national borders in Europe divide language groups.
Japan’s national border is the sea.
Chile’s national border with Argentina is the Andes Mountains.
Mexico’s national border with the USA is a river, the Rio Grande.
There is a straight line between the USA and Canada.
Many national borders in Africa are also straight lines.
European countries made most of these lines.

3-1.title: The North Pole and the South Pole

sentences.text: This is the Earth.
At the top of the Earth is the North Pole.
At the bottom of the Earth is the South Pole.
The North Pole is in the Arctic Sea.
The Arctic Sea is very cold.
The South Pole is in Antarctica.
Antarctica is also very cold.
How far is the North Pole from the South Pole?
About twenty thousand kilometers.
Look at the red line on the map.
This line is the Equator.
How far is the Equator from the North Pole?
About ten thousand kilometers.
The distance is about ten thousand kilometers.
How far is the Equator from the South Pole?
About ten thousand kilometers.
The distances are equal.
Equal, Equate, Equator.
The Equator.
Countries near the Equator are hot.
Latitude lines are parallel with the Equator.
The distance between them is always the same.
The Equator is at zero degrees latitude.
The North Pole is at ninety degrees north latitude.
The South Pole is at ninety degrees south latitude.
Latitude is the angle between lines from the Earth's center.
Ten thousand kilometers divided by ninety is about one hundred eleven kilometers.
One degree latitude is about one hundred eleven kilometers.
Ten degrees latitude is about one thousand one hundred eleven kilometers.
Longitude lines connect the North Pole and the South Pole.
Longitude lines are not parallel.
Longitude is also the angle between lines from the Earth's center.
One degree longitude is about one hundred eleven kilometers at the Equator.
One degree longitude is zero kilometers at the North Pole.
One degree longitude near Hirosaki is about eighty-five kilometers.
The Prime Meridian goes through London.
London is at zero degrees longitude.
West of London is West Longitude.
East of London is East Longitude.
The one hundred eighty degree meridian is in the Pacific Ocean.
One hundred eighty degrees west longitude equals one hundred eighty degrees east longitude.
We can use latitude and longitude to find Hirosaki.
Latitude and longitude for Hirosaki are forty point six degrees north latitude and one hundred forty point five degrees east longitude.
These are Hirosaki’s geographic coordinates.
We can use latitude and longitude to find Melbourne.
Latitude and longitude for Melbourne are thirty-seven point eight degrees south latitude and one hundred forty-five point zero degrees east longitude.
These are Melbourne’s geographic coordinates.
This is Melbourne in Australia.
What is the weather like in Melbourne today?
What is weather?
Weather is sunny, cloudy, rainy, snowy, and windy.
What is the weather like today?
It is sunny.
Is it sunny in Melbourne every day?
No, sometimes it is cloudy.
Sometimes it is rainy.
Sometimes it is windy.
But it is never snowy.
What is the climate like in Melbourne?
What is climate?
Weather is sunny, cloudy, rainy, snowy, and windy.
Climate is Polar, Tropical, Temperate, and Arid.
What is a Polar Climate?
The climate near the North Pole is Polar.
The climate near the South Pole is Polar.
Polar bears live in the Polar Zone.
In the Polar Zone, it is always cold.
What is a Tropical Climate?
This is tropical fruit, and these are tropical fish.
Look at the red line on the map.
This line is the Equator.
Countries near the Equator are Tropical.
The Tropical Zone is always hot.
What is a Temperate Climate?
Hirosaki has a Temperate Climate.
Hirosaki has hot summers.
Hirosaki has cold winters.
Temperate Climates have summers and winters.
What is an Arid Climate?
The Arid Zone has little rain.
The Sahara Desert is Arid.
Climate is Polar (always cold), Tropical (always hot), Temperate (has summers and winters), and Arid (has little rain).
So, what is the climate like in Melbourne?
Melbourne has a Temperate Climate.
